dataCollected: Everything you post, like, share, or comment on
Who you talk to and how often
What you look at and for how long
Data from other apps on your phone
Your browsing history across the web (via pixel tracking)
facebook.com.howAlgorithmWorks: Facebook shows you stuff that keeps you scrolling. It learns what makes you angry, sad, or excited—then feeds you more of that. Outrage = engagement = ad money. It creates filter bubbles where you only see views you already agree with.
psyOps: Infinite scroll - no natural stopping point, keeps you hooked
Variable rewards - like a slot machine, you never know when you'll get likes
Social validation - exploits your need for approval
FOMO - fear of missing out keeps you checking back
Notification bombardment - constant pings to pull you back in
whatToCheck: Settings → Privacy → Download your data (prepare to be shocked)
Settings → Your Facebook Information → Off-Facebook Activity
Ad Preferences - see how they've profiled you
alternatives: Mastodon - decentralized, no algorithm pushing content
Signal groups - for actual private communication

dataCollected: All your photos and their metadata (location, time)
Your face and faces of people in your photos
What you look at and for how long
instagram.com.howAlgorithmWorks: Instagram's algorithm is designed to make you feel inadequate so you keep scrolling for validation. It prioritizes content that triggers comparison and envy. Reels are TikTok-style dopamine hits to maximize time on app.
psyOps: Comparison trap - curated highlights make your life seem worse
Beauty filters - distort reality, damage self-image
Like counts - gamifies social validation
Explore page - rabbit hole designed to waste hours
Stories urgency - 24hr limit creates artificial FOMO
whatToCheck: Download your data to see everything stored
alternatives: VSCO - more focused on creativity, less on validation

dataCollected: All tweets, likes, retweets, and bookmarks
Who you follow and interact with
twitter.com.howAlgorithmWorks: X/Twitter amplifies controversial and emotional content because it drives engagement. The algorithm is trained to maximize time on site. Political content and outrage get boosted because they generate reactions.
psyOps: Outrage amplification - anger spreads faster than facts
Quote tweet pile-ons - mob mentality by design
Trending manipulation - creates artificial urgency
Blue check validation - pay for visibility
Character limit - forces oversimplification of complex topics
alternatives: Mastodon - federated, choose your own algorithm
RSS feeds - you control what you see

dataCollected: All tweets, likes, retweets, and bookmarks
Who you follow and interact with
x.com.howAlgorithmWorks: X/Twitter amplifies controversial and emotional content because it drives engagement. The algorithm is trained to maximize time on site. Political content and outrage get boosted because they generate reactions.
psyOps: Outrage amplification - anger spreads faster than facts
Quote tweet pile-ons - mob mentality by design
Trending manipulation - creates artificial urgency
Blue check validation - pay for visibility
Character limit - forces oversimplification of complex topics
alternatives: Mastodon - federated, choose your own algorithm
RSS feeds - you control what you see

dataCollected: Everything you watch and for exactly how long
tiktok.com.howAlgorithmWorks: TikTok has the most advanced recommendation algorithm. It learns your preferences within minutes by tracking exactly what you pause on, rewatch, or skip. It's essentially a behavior prediction engine that knows you better than you know yourself.
psyOps: Hyper-personalization - creates an addiction loop tuned to YOUR brain
Short-form content - trains attention span to need constant stimulation
Endless scroll - no stopping cues
Sound-on autoplay - hijacks attention involuntarily
Trend pressure - fear of being 'out of the loop'
alternatives: YouTube (with uBlock) - at least you control recommendations more
Learning a musical instrument - equally stimulating, actually rewarding

youtube.com.howAlgorithmWorks: YouTube's algorithm optimizes for watch time, not quality. It learns to recommend increasingly extreme content because that keeps people watching. The rabbit hole effect can lead people from cooking videos to conspiracy theories in a few clicks.
psyOps: Autoplay - removes the decision to stop watching
Recommendations sidebar - always something 'better' to watch
Thumbnail manipulation - clickbait imagery
Watch time optimization - longer videos = more ads
Notification overload - 'Don't miss out!'

google.com.howAlgorithmWorks: Google creates a comprehensive profile of you across all services. Search results are personalized to keep you in a filter bubble. They sell this profile to advertisers who then follow you everywhere online.
psyOps: Convenience trap - services so good you can't leave
Data lock-in - your whole digital life is with them
Normalization - 'everyone uses Google'
Free illusion - you pay with your data, not money

dataCollected: Browsing and search history on Amazon
amazon.com.howAlgorithmWorks: Amazon's algorithm is designed to maximize purchases. It tracks what you look at, how long, what you almost bought, and uses this to hit you with 'personalized' deals. Prime creates artificial urgency and loyalty.
psyOps: Prime lock-in - sunk cost keeps you buying
One-click buying - removes friction for impulse purchases
Artificial scarcity - 'Only 3 left!' creates urgency
Review manipulation - hard to trust what's real
Subscribe & Save - autopilot spending
whatToCheck: Alexa Privacy Settings - review voice recordings
Advertising Preferences - opt out of personalized ads
alternatives: Direct from brands - often same price

linkedin.com.howAlgorithmWorks: LinkedIn's algorithm promotes 'engagement bait' - emotional stories that perform well regardless of professional value. It creates pressure to constantly 'build your brand' and anxiety about career progress.
psyOps: Status anxiety - constant comparison to peers
Hustle culture glorification - burnout as aspiration
Engagement pressure - must post to be visible
Connection FOMO - larger network = more success?
Premium FOMO - pay to see who viewed you
whatToCheck: Settings → Get a copy of your data
alternatives: Personal website - own your professional presence
Direct networking - actual relationships matter more
Industry-specific communities - more focused, less noise

reddit.com.howAlgorithmWorks: Reddit's algorithm promotes content that generates engagement (votes, comments). Controversial content often rises because it generates discussion. Echo chambers form naturally in subreddits.
psyOps: Karma system - gamifies social validation
Infinite communities - always another rabbit hole
Upvote dopamine - slot machine for opinions
Default sorting - algorithm decides 'best'
Awards - monetized validation

snapchat.com.howAlgorithmWorks: Snapchat creates urgency through disappearing content. Streaks exploit social obligation. The Discover feed is algorithmic content designed to maximize engagement.
psyOps: Streaks - artificial social obligations
Disappearing content - creates urgency to check constantly
Snap Map - social pressure + surveillance
Beauty filters - body dysmorphia fuel
Snap Score - gamified usage tracking
whatToCheck: Settings → My Data → Download My Data
Snap Map settings - who can see you?
alternatives: Regular texting - good enough for most things

dataCollected: What you pause, rewind, or skip
netflix.com.howAlgorithmWorks: Netflix's algorithm is designed to keep you watching. It personalizes thumbnails, recommendations, and even what order things appear. The goal is maximizing 'time engaged' with the platform.
psyOps: Auto-play next episode - removes decision to stop
Personalized thumbnails - A/B tested to hook YOU
Skip intro - removes natural stopping point
Are you still watching? - just often enough
New releases - creates watching obligations
whatToCheck: Account → Profile & Parental Controls → Viewing restrictions
alternatives: Buying/renting individual titles - own what you watch

spotify.com.howAlgorithmWorks: Spotify's algorithm creates filter bubbles in music. It learns your taste and keeps feeding you similar content, which can actually limit musical discovery despite claiming to enhance it.
psyOps: Personalized playlists - makes you dependent on algorithm
Wrapped - gamifies your listening data
Premium pressure - constant upselling
Social features - what will people think of your taste?
Infinite playlists - background noise optimization
alternatives: Local music files - own your collection

dataCollected: Metadata - who you talk to, when, how often
whatsapp.com.howAlgorithmWorks: While messages are encrypted, Meta collects extensive metadata about your communication patterns. This metadata is incredibly revealing about your relationships, routines, and life.
psyOps: Network effect - everyone's on it, so you must be
Read receipts - social pressure to respond
Online status - surveillance normalized
Group pressure - can't leave without drama
Status feature - Instagram stories for messaging
whatToCheck: Linked devices - who else has access?

discord.com.howAlgorithmWorks: Discord doesn't have a traditional feed algorithm, but it creates stickiness through always-on community presence. The fear of missing out on conversations keeps people perpetually connected.
psyOps: Always-on presence - constant social monitoring
Notification overload - every message pings
Server FOMO - can't track all conversations
Nitro upselling - pay for better expression
Activity status - work and play monitored
whatToCheck: Settings → Privacy & Safety → Request all of my data
Settings → Privacy & Safety → review all toggles
alternatives: Revolt - Discord alternative focused on privacy

dataCollected: Windows telemetry (everything you do on PC)
microsoft.com.howAlgorithmWorks: Microsoft builds a comprehensive profile through Windows, Office, and cloud services. This data informs advertising and product decisions. Windows 11 has increased telemetry and AI integration.
psyOps: Platform lock-in - Office format dominance
Default settings - maximum data collection
Update pressure - can't avoid changes
Cloud push - your files on their servers
AI integration - Copilot everywhere
whatToCheck: Windows Settings → Privacy - dozens of settings
Microsoft Privacy Statement - it's very long for a reason

apple.com.howAlgorithmWorks: Apple positions itself as privacy-focused but still collects significant data. Siri data is processed, iCloud isn't end-to-end encrypted by default, and App Tracking Transparency still allows first-party tracking.
psyOps: Ecosystem lock-in - very hard to leave
Status symbol marketing - identity through product
Planned obsolescence - forced upgrades
Privacy marketing - creates false sense of security
Premium pricing - you still pay AND they get data
alternatives: Android with GrapheneOS - truly private phone

twitch.tv.howAlgorithmWorks: Twitch's recommendation system keeps you watching. It suggests streams based on your history and what keeps people engaged. The parasocial relationship design keeps viewers coming back.
psyOps: Parasocial relationships - false sense of friendship
Subscription pressure - 'support your streamer'
Bits/donations - gamified spending
Chat engagement - belonging to community
FOMO on live content - can't pause life
whatToCheck: Connections - what's linked to your account
Subscription history - how much have you spent?

pinterest.com.howAlgorithmWorks: Pinterest is designed to show you things you might buy. The algorithm learns your aesthetic preferences and shopping interests, then surfaces products disguised as inspiration.
psyOps: Aspiration exploitation - creates desire for lifestyle
Shopping disguised as inspiration
Infinite scroll of wanting
Comparison culture - curated perfection
Wedding/baby planning pressure
